CHESTERFIELD

Chesterfield Contest
Contest statisticians were forced to use of the slide-rule in
determining the winner of last week's Chesterfield carton.
When the last decimal point was correctly placed, however,
ED THOET was deemed winner with Bob Byron and Bill Sopev
close seconds. Each picked nine winners, but score accuracy
swung the balance in the favor of Thoet. DICK BROWN
had his name placed on the door list of next week's H Club
dance by making the closest call on the Hopkins-Swarthmore
game. This week's games:
All entries must be in the News-Letter office by noon
Saturday.

One of the strongest pieces of evidence
that mechanical engineering is of major
significance in the Du Pont Company is
the existence of the Wilmington Shops.
They represent an investment of over
$3,500,000 and cover an area of 300,000
sq. ft., including a foundry and pattern
shop. They employ over 800 men and
have a potential output in volume of
work in excess of $6,000,000 a year.
The size and diversity of this operation
are justified only because the work of
mechanical engineers is an important
factor in Du Pont operations.

USED BOOK PLANS
Several plans eoncerning the sale of used books have been
put into effect in past years but none has worked .well either for
the students or the group which sold them. This problem has
carried from ,one year to another and should be solved now.
Since there have been so many ideas set forth as to methods of
handling used books it seems apparent that no one wants to be
bothered with the excess work which arises from buying and
re-selling these books.
(

Homewood, Baltimore, November 9, 1951

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE FOUR

The Bookstore certainly should be the organization to handle
used books. It is already supposed to be handling used books
as a result of Student Council action last year. Evidently they do
not care for the present arrangement as is evidenced by new plans
which have been released by this year's Student Council.
Under one plan the Bookstore will buy the books from students
giving them a fifty percent return on the list price. The Bookstoi:e
will re-sell the books at seventy-five percent of the original price.
In both instances the prices offered are too high. Students interested in used books are looking for something inexpensive, not a
book just twenty-five percent less than the price of a new text.
The best plan seems to be that set forth by the Sudent Council.
They suggested that used books be sold by students working under
concession rules through the Bureau of Appointments. This would
appear to be the logical system. Under this plan, students with a
direct financial interest would insure the plan's success and more
than likely the high prices offered in the first plan by the Bookstore
could be reduced considerably.

Campaign Fizzled .

Last year the News-Letter started a campaign at the end of the
football season to have Eddie Miller placed on the little All American squad. It failed because the publicity was started too
late. However, the situation for choosing the team in soccer is
different so public opinion won't weigh too heavily. Still, a little
support from the press never hurt any candidate.
To Jimmy Smith goes the well wishes of the Hopkins campus.
The soccer team still has two games left, one with Delaware tomorrow at Homewood and another with Loyola next week, also at home.
After that there will be.a month or two wait, before the standings
come out. This writer sincerely hopes Jim will be on that All
American team.
Note: While on the subject of All Americans, the lacrosse
All American team will not be announced until the middle of
December.

Turner Satisfied
Head Coach Marshall Turner
was satisfied with the improvement his charges showed. He was
pleased with the inside running
attack and the improved passing
offense.
Turner felt that the pass defense and defensive end play were
improved, but still left much to
be desired.
Line-backer Gene Carstens and
Jack
Allen
were outstanding
along with the middle of the yearling Jay line in thwarting Swarthmore's single wing attack.
With regular hooter Yank Samberg on the injured list, the kicking was done by tackle Buzzy Williams and halfback Ray Forthuber.
Halfback Pete Chant and tackle
Johnny Bratten were co-captains
for the game.

Thursday afternoon they held the
Maryland Scholastic leaders, Calvert Hall, to a scoreless tie. The
team, despite the fact that it was
playing its first game of the season, showed great group work that
stymied the highly favored Calvert Hall team.

MACTFACC
At Allentown
The 24th Annual .Middle Atlantic Collegiate Track and Field Association Cross-country Championship are being run today at 3 p.m.
at Cedar Park, Allentown, Penn-.
sylvania. For the first time in
many a year Hopkins will send a
full team to the meet, which is
under the joint sponsorship of
Muhlenberg College and the Association.
LaSalle and St. Joseph's Colleges are the pre-meet favorites
for tlie team championship. St.
Joseph's is the defending champion. They romped over a field
of 13 teams last year as they
placed five men in the first seven
individual finishers.
LaSalle tied for third last year,
but have some very good lip-andcoming freshmen and sophomore
harriers. Earl Eldridge, Charles
Harmon, and Joe Merkins have
been the mainstays of the LaSalle
team thus far this year and are
expected to finish among the first
ten or fifteen finishers.
David Henderson, of Lehigh,
third in last year's race, Avery
Harrington of Swarthmore, Bill
Reybold and Ralph Fouracre of
Delaware, and our own Don Manger will fight it out with the LaSalle and St. Joseph's stars for
individual honors in the race.. All
of these hill-and-dalers will be
gunning for the Cedar Park course
record of 22 minutes and five seconds set last year by Cunningham
of St. Joseph's in the championships.

USED BOOK PLANS
Several plans eoncerning the sale of used books have been
put into effect in past years but none has worked .well either for
the students or the group which sold them. This problem has
carried from ,one year to another and should be solved now.
Since there have been so many ideas set forth as to methods of
handling used books it seems apparent that no one wants to be
bothered with the excess work which arises from buying and
re-selling these books.
(

Homewood, Baltimore, November 9, 1951

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE FOUR

The Bookstore certainly should be the organization to handle
used books. It is already supposed to be handling used books
as a result of Student Council action last year. Evidently they do
not care for the present arrangement as is evidenced by new plans
which have been released by this year's Student Council.
Under one plan the Bookstore will buy the books from students
giving them a fifty percent return on the list price. The Bookstoi:e
will re-sell the books at seventy-five percent of the original price.
In both instances the prices offered are too high. Students interested in used books are looking for something inexpensive, not a
book just twenty-five percent less than the price of a new text.
The best plan seems to be that set forth by the Sudent Council.
They suggested that used books be sold by students working under
concession rules through the Bureau of Appointments. This would
appear to be the logical system. Under this plan, students with a
direct financial interest would insure the plan's success and more
than likely the high prices offered in the first plan by the Bookstore
could be reduced considerably.

Last year the News-Letter started a campaign at the end of the
football season to have Eddie Miller placed on the little All American squad. It failed because the publicity was started too
late. However, the situation for choosing the team in soccer is
different so public opinion won't weigh too heavily. Still, a little
support from the press never hurt any candidate.
To Jimmy Smith goes the well wishes of the Hopkins campus.
The soccer team still has two games left, one with Delaware tomorrow at Homewood and another with Loyola next week, also at home.
After that there will be.a month or two wait, before the standings
come out. This writer sincerely hopes Jim will be on that All
American team.

Turner Satisfied
Head Coach Marshall Turner
was satisfied with the improvement his charges showed. He was
pleased with the inside running
attack and the improved passing
offense.
Turner felt that the pass defense and defensive end play were
improved, but still left much to
be desired.
Line-backer Gene Carstens and
Jack
Allen
were outstanding
along with the middle of the yearling Jay line in thwarting Swarthmore's single wing attack.
With regular hooter Yank Samberg on the injured list, the kicking was done by tackle Buzzy Williams and halfback Ray Forthuber.
Halfback Pete Chant and tackle
Johnny Bratten were co-captains
for the game.

At Allentown
The 24th Annual .Middle Atlantic Collegiate Track and Field Association Cross-country Championship are being run today at 3 p.m.
at Cedar Park, Allentown, Penn-.
sylvania. For the first time in
many a year Hopkins will send a
full team to the meet, which is
under the joint sponsorship of
Muhlenberg College and the Association.
LaSalle and St. Joseph's Colleges are the pre-meet favorites
for tlie team championship. St.
Joseph's is the defending champion. They romped over a field
of 13 teams last year as they
placed five men in the first seven
individual finishers.
LaSalle tied for third last year,
but have some very good lip-andcoming freshmen and sophomore
harriers. Earl Eldridge, Charles
Harmon, and Joe Merkins have
been the mainstays of the LaSalle
team thus far this year and are
expected to finish among the first
ten or fifteen finishers.
David Henderson, of Lehigh,
third in last year's race, Avery
Harrington of Swarthmore, Bill
Reybold and Ralph Fouracre of
Delaware, and our own Don Manger will fight it out with the LaSalle and St. Joseph's stars for
individual honors in the race.. All
of these hill-and-dalers will be
gunning for the Cedar Park course
record of 22 minutes and five seconds set last year by Cunningham
of St. Joseph's in the championships.
